‘⁶ The truth is that nothing is slower, more insidious, or more unnoticed in its action than the change that is constantly going on in langnage. One generation of men passes away, another generation comes, and each man believes with all the earnestness of conviction that he speaks the language of his fathers, when in trnth he does nothing of the kind. He does not even speak the language of his youth, much less that of his father’s youth, for in his own mouth and without his knowledge the change is being effected.
